For example, i n a previous case the Commission made a distinction between originator and generic medicinal products stating that there is a separate market for the wholesale of generic medicines as compared to the wholesale of proprietary medicines. In oth er cases, however, the Commission set out that where the market is genericised, originator drugs and generics could be considered to be close substitutes for a given indication and a product market may be defined as including both the generic and the proprietary medicine.

topic: Product Market Definition Based on ATC Level
text: Given the characteristics of the products involved in the present case (mature genericised medicinal products), the Commission takes the molecule level as the most plausible starting point for the product market definition. Where th ere is no overlap at molecule level , the Commission takes the ATC3 or ATC4 level as a starting point reference to assess therapeutic and economic substitutability across molecules . In the present case the exact ATC level and the question whether ATC3 need to be further segmented to ATC4 can be left open as the Transaction does not raise doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market irrespective of the precise market definition.

topic: Product Market Definition Including Both Generic and Originator Versions
text: Regarding a potential distinction between originator and generic produ cts d uring the market investigation in the present case the respondents did not point out specificities other than brand recognition and price that differentiate the originator products from the generic products. In this regard, even if brand loyalty to the originator medicine may play a role in limiting switching in certain instances, competition takes place between originator and generic providers. Therefore, for the purposes of the competitive assessment of the Transaction , the Commission considers t hat in relation to the overlapping molecules the product market includes both generic and originator versions in relation to the overlapping molecules.

topic: Geographic Market Definition for Finished Pharmaceutical Products
text: As regards the geographic market definition, the Notifying Party has submit ted an overview of the overlapping activities on a country -by country basis. T he Commission has consistently held that the market for finished pharmaceutical products is national in scope. This conclusion has been reached because of (i) varying regulatory controls for pharmaceutical products; (ii) perceived differences in price setting and purchasing patterns/reimbursement by Member States; (iii) differences in national clinical guidelines , medical views and patient preferences; (iv) differences in brand, pack size and distribution system; and (v) because competition between pharmaceutical companies generally takes place at national level.

In both countries, however, Intas is facing recent entrants as well as likely further ma rket entries in the near future . Indeed, in Poland , there are a large numb er of competitors who have marketing authoris ation s. In particular, two competitors are already present on the market ([…], and […]) following the acqui sition of a marketing authoris ation s in the last two year s. Furthermore , five additional competitors ( […]) hold a recently obtained marketing authoris ation . Out of these five players , […] has recently won a tender while […] is expected to launch its product very shortly . The three other players have dormant marketing authorisations. Given the high level of recent entry and the increasing competitive pressure that Intas is facing in Poland, the overlap between its marketed […] product and the EEA -wide pipeline for the same molecule it will acquire as part of the Other EEA Divestment Business does not raise p rima facie competitive concerns.

In Norway, Intas , whose market position has weakened in recent months, would face significant competition from […] and […]. In particular, strong competition can be expected from […], who entered the market in January 2017 and is rapidly growing . In addition, there are four other competitors who already have marketing authoris ation s and are thus able to impose a competitive constraint on Intas post -acquisition , namely […]. Out of these four dormant marketing authoris ation holders, […] acquired the m in the last two years, suggesting that a launch of these products in the near term is likely. Furthermore, Teva is planning to launch its […] product in Norway in early 2019. Given the hi gh level of recent entry and the increasing competitive pressure that Intas is facing in Norway, the overlap between its marketed […] product and the EEA -wide pipeline for the same molecule it will acquire as part of the Other EEA Divestment Business does not raise prima facie competitive concerns.

topic: Oxaliplatin and Alendronic acid relevant product market
text: As for vertical overlaps, the Out-licensing Divestment Business only has sales to customers regarding molecule/country pairs for which Intas already has an on-market product for (i) oxaliplatin in the Czech Republic and in Germany as well as (ii) alendronic acid in the Netherlands. Given the limited combined market shares of Intas and the Out-licensing Divestment Business ' licensees for these molecule/country pairs and the number and strength of active competitors , namely Accord Healthcare, Actavis, Ebewe, Hospira, Kabi Pharmacia, STADA, Teva, Sanofi -Aventis, Merck, Mylan, Medac, Egis, Bendalis, Omnicare, Onkovis, Haemato Pharm, Ribosepharm and Cancernova for oxali platin in the Czech Republic and in Germany as well as Mylan, Sandoz, Teva, Pharmachemie, Will, Actavis, Aurobindo, Bioeq Pharma, Bluefish, Centrafarm, Curaphar, MSD , Mibe, Osteonorm and Steovess for alendronic acid in the Netherlands, these overlaps would not create prima facie competition concerns.

As for horizontal overlaps, Intas only has outlicensing activities in the EEA for one molecule included in the Outlicensing Divestment Business, oxaliplatin . In view of the fact that 11 competitors, namely Fresenius Kabi, Hospira, Teva, Qilu, Sandoz, Sun Pharma, Mylan, Cadila Pharma, Pharmascience, Stragen and Medac, are active as outlicensors for oxaliplatin , this overlap would not create prima facie competition concerns.

As for Fluconazole , Alvogen would face strong co mpetition post -transaction from Teva (ex -Allergan) which would be of a comparable size. Concerning Losartan , Teva (ex -Allergan) would remain the market leader, Alvogen would also face competition from Merck and Valeant. As for Menantine , Alvogen would face competition from Williams & Halls , which would be of a comparable size, and to a lesser extent from H Lundbeck . As for Rizatriptan N2C , post -transaction Alvogen would face competition from Merck, which is the market leader by far.

Each of these markets is highly competitive. For instance atorvastatin in Hungary faces competition from 1A Pharma, Actavis, Aramis, Dr. Schlichtinger, ExtractumPharma, Egis, Gedeon, Glenmark Pharmaceutical, Goodwill, Pharma-Regist, Richter, Pfizer, Krka, Polpharma, Q Pharma, Ranbaxy, Pharma-Regist, Teva, Wörwag Pharma and Zentiva.
Each of these markets is highly competitive. Granisetron in Romania faces competition from Actavis, Teva, Egis, Fresenius and Dr. Reddy's

Each of these markets is highly competitive. Finally, paracetamol in Romania faces competition from Accord Healthcare, Antibiotice, Arena, Biofarm, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Europharm, Farmex, Fabiol, Fresenius Kabi, Krka, Magistra, McNeil, Meduman, Pharmaceutical Works, Pharmex, Ozone Laboratories, Sanosan, Sintofarm, Zentiva, GlaxoSmithKline, Labormed Pharma, Panpharma, Terapia, Laropharm, TIS Farmaceutic, Novartis, Rompharm and Grünenthal.

The Parties consider that the activities of the target companies are in the market for the wholesale of IT products, specifically hardware, software, cloud solutions and services dedicated to enterprise IT security and software defined data centres.
The Commission has in previous decisions considered the overall market for wholesale of IT products and has also considered narrower product markets for the wholesale of specific IT products, such as, inter alia, data storage products, software, and IT security products.
The Commission has also considered the geographic scope of these markets to be at least national in scope.
The Commission considers that it is not necessary to conclude on the precise product or geographic market definition in the present case, since the proposed transaction would not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market under any plausible market definition.

In its reasoned proposal, Teva presented an analysis of the overlaps between Rivopharm and the Divestment Business. This analysis was performed at molecule and galenic form levels. The result of this analysis is that no horizontal overlap exists. With respect to vertical overlaps, Rivopharm does not have any outlicensing activities for the molecule/country pairs which are included in the Divestment Business. However, a vertical overlap exists for gabapentin in Sweden as Rivopharm supplies gabapentin to one customer which sells the product under its own brand and livery. This vertical overlap is however unlikely to give rise to any prima facie competition concern for the following reasons. First, Rivopharm's customer is the marketing authori sation holder and thus is the one selling this product . Second, in 2016, the combined market share of Rivopharm's product and the Divested Product was below the 30% threshold both in value (21%) and volume (14%) . Third, strong competitors are present on th e market, notably Teva (with a market share in value of 37%) and Novartis (with a market share in value of 22%).

topic: Wholesale of Generics in the UK and Ireland
text: Under the Proposed Agreements, these molecules  are carved out from the sale. Pursuant to paragraph 46 of the Commitments, " the Commission may approve the sale of the Divestment Businesses without one or more Assets or parts of the Personnel, or by substituting one or more Assets or parts of the Personnel, if this does not affect the viability and competitiveness of the Divestment Businesses after the sale, taking into account the proposed purchaser(s) ." In the Decision, among the five molecules concerned, the Commission identified serious doubts as to the compatibility of the transaction with the internal market for one molecule (doxorubicin in Ireland). The other four molecules were part of the Commitments so as to solve the Commission's serious doubts in the markets for the wholesale of generics in the UK and Ireland.

Teva argues that, to the extent Intas already has a significant coverage in the UK and Ireland, the five molecules carved out do not in any way affect the viability and competitiveness of the Divestment Business and are not necessary to solve the Commission's serious doubts in relation to the markets for the wholesale of generics in the UK and Ireland. In particular, Teva submits that the combined entity (Intas and the IE -UK Divestment Businesses) will reach a wider coverage in terms of number of molecules, sales and margins than the full IE -UK Divestment Businesses. However, to solve the serious doubts identified at molecule level for doxorubicin in Ireland, Teva commits to divest this molecule in Ireland to another purchaser.

The Commission concluded in the Decision that the market for debt collection and the market for debt purchasing are both national in scope. Lowell Group mainly operates in the UK, Germany, Austria and Switzerland and has some minor activities in Slovenia and Croatia. Lowell Group does not have any debt collection and debt purchasing activities in the countries where the Divestment Business is active , i.e. Norway, Sweden, Finland, Denmark and Estonia. There is therefore no horizontal overlap between the activities of purchaser and the Divestment Business in the EEA.

The Commission concluded in the Decision that the market for debt collection and the market for debt purchasing are both national in scope. Lowell Group mainly operates in the UK, Germany, Austria and Switzerland and has some minor activities in Slovenia and Croatia. Lowell Group does not have any debt collection and debt purchasing activities in the countries where the Divestment Business is active , i.e. Norway, Sweden, Finland, Denmark and Estonia. There is therefore no horizontal overlap between the activities of purchaser and the Divestment Business in the EEA.
The Commission notes that, in previous decisions, it has defined product markets in relation to asset management and investment services, real estate and the provision of energy.
The Commission notes that, in previous decisions, it has defined product markets in relation to asset management and investment services, real estate and the provision of energy.
The Commission notes that, in previous decisions, it has defined product markets in relation to asset management and investment services, real estate and the provision of energy.

topic: Precise Product or Geographic Market Definition
text: The Commission considers that it is not necessary to conclude on the precise product or geographic market definition in the present case, since the transaction does not raise serious doubts under any plausible market definition.

Detergents: The Commission has previously considered that there could be a separate segment for detergents, as compared to dispersants, but left the product market definition open. The Commission has suggested a possible subsegmentation of detergents based on the chemical group: (i) sulphonates; (ii) phenates; and (iii) salicylates; it however finally left open the product market definition. The Notifying Party considers that it is not necessary to sub-divide the market further.

topic: Chemical intermediates for the production of lubricant additives
text: Chemical intermediates for the production of lubricant additives There are multiple chemical intermediates used in the production of lubricant additives. Aniline and diphenylamine ("DPA") are two such chemical intermediates, used as an input for aminic primary antioxidants and other lubricant additives. The Commission has not previously analysed the markets for aniline or DPA. The Notifying Party submits that the precise market definition can be left open in this case. Vertically affected markets arise in relation to antioxidants and the sub-segment of aminic antioxidants for which aniline and DPA are inputs and are therefore considered below in the competitive assessment. For the purposes of the present decision, the exact product market definition for chemical intermediates, in particular aniline and DPA, can be left open since the Proposed Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market

Flame retardants are chemicals incorporated into a variety of manufactured materials to increase their resistance to ignition, or by acting to slow down combustion. The Notifying Party submits that flame retardants should be sub-segmented according to the chemistry used, for exa mple: (i) brominated; (ii) chlorinated; (iii) aluminium tri-hydroxide based; and (iv) phosphorus based. It argues that it would not be appropriate to sub-segment the market further based on end application, for exa mple for use in: (i) PVC; (ii) polyamides; or (iii) polyurethane ("PU"); because the same type of flame retardants can be used for different applications and different types of flame retardants can be used for the same application. The Commission has previously noted that flame retardants can differ depending on the chemistry used or on the basis of the application but that manufacturers of flame retardants can use different inputs to achieve flame retardants with comparable characteristics. The Commission found that the market could potentially be sub-segmented by type but it ultimately left the market definition open, undertaking the assessment based on the market broken down by chemistry and end application. The market investigation was inconclusive as to whether it would be appropriate to further segment the market according to chemistry used. The vast majority of respondents consider that flame retardants based on different chemistries can be used for the same end applications in some cases, but not all. In turn, the market investigation was also inconclusive as to whether it could be appropriate to sub-segment either phosphorus or bromine based flame retardants according to end use. The vast majority of respondents consider that products based on a particular chemistry are partially interchangeable in that they can be used for some end-applications, but not all. In particular, a slight majority consider that certain phosphorus based flame retardants are better suited for PVC applications and the majority of respondents consider that certain phosphorus based flame retardants are better suited for PU applications. A horizontally affected market arises in relation to bromine based flame retardants and a few market participants raised concerns regarding phosphorus based flame retardants which are therefore considered below in the competitive assessment. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact scope of the product market definition for flame retardants and its sub-segments therein can be left open, since no serious doubts as to the compatibility of the Proposed Transaction with the internal market arise, regardless of whether the market is considered to be broken down by chemistry or further broken down by end application.

Trimethylolpropane ("TMP") is a polyhydric alcohol that serves, inter alia, as an input into trimethylolpropane branched hydroxyl terminated saturated polyester and it is, thus, a common building block in the polymer industry. Chemtura uses TMP for the production of: (i) resins; (ii) PU-hardeners; and (iii) lubricant products; although it also has other uses. The Commission has previously considered whether TMP is part of an overall market for polyhydric alcohols or forms a separate product market but has left the product market definition open. It has never considered further segmenting the market for TMP. The Notifying Party considers that TMP is substitutable with other polyhydric alcohols therefore that the relevant market should be defined as including all polyhydric alcohols. Moreover, the Notifying Party submits that it supplies one grade of TMP for all applications. A vertically affected market arises in relation to the supply of TMP therefore this market which is therefore considered below in the competitive assessment. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact scope of the product market definition for the supply of TMP can be left open, since no serious doubts as to the compatibility of the Proposed Transaction with the internal market arise even under the narrowest possible market definition (that is TMP).
The Commission investigated the conditions of competition for mobile payments.
The geographic market covered by this Decision is France.

The products concerned by this Decision are consumer electronic products that fall within the categories of Personal Care, Lifestyle Entertainment, Health & Wellness and Domestic Appliances, as listed in section 2.1 above.

Concerning the product market definition, the Commission has in previous decisions considered that free-standing ovens constitute a separate product market, distinct from built-in ovens, as the latter are permanently fitted into kitchen furniture and require installation. Free-standing ovens are ready to use and are sold through different channels. However, in previous decisions, the Commission left the question open as to whether free-standing ovens constitute a separate product market. For the purpose of this decision, it is not necessary to conclude on the exact product market definition, since the transaction does not raise serious doubts under any alternative market definition considered.

In previous decisions, the Commission has considered the market for cooking appliances, comprising ovens, hob plates, cooking stoves, and ranges. The Commission’s market investigation in Electrolux/Roper also indicated that there is a demand side substitutability between different cooking appliances, in particular between hob plates and cooking stoves. However, in previous decisions, the Commission left the question open as to the exact scope of the product market for cooking appliances. For the purpose of this decision, it is not necessary to conclude on the exact product market definition, since the transaction does not raise serious doubts under any alternative market definition considered.

Concerning the product market definition, the Commission has in previous decisions considered that dishwashers constitute a separate product market. The Commission has in previous decisions distinguished between household dishwashers and industrial dishwashers. For the purpose of this decision, it is not necessary to conclude on the exact product market definition, since the transaction does not raise serious doubts under any alternative market definition considered.

Concerning the product market definition, the Commission has in previous decisions considered that refrigerators constitute a separate product market. The Commission has in previous decisions distinguished between household refrigerators and industrial refrigerators. For the purpose of this decision, it is not necessary to conclude on the exact product market definition, since the transaction does not raise serious doubts under any alternative market definition considered.

Concerning the product market definition, the Commission has in previous decisions considered that washing machines constitute a separate product market. The Commission has in previous decisions distinguished between household washing machines and industrial washing machines. For the purpose of this decision, it is not necessary to conclude on the exact product market definition, since the transaction does not raise serious doubts under any alternative market definition considered.

In previous decisions, the Commission has found that, from a demand-side perspective, retailers constitute a separate market, as retailers cannot switch to alternative suppliers if the manufacturers of large household appliances were to increase prices. From the supply-side perspective, retailers do not exert a sufficient constraint on manufacturers of large household appliances, as retailers need to offer a complete range of products to customers. For the purpose of this decision, it is not necessary to conclude on the exact product market definition, since the transaction does not raise serious doubts under any alternative market definition considered.

topic: Supply of hot-rolled flat carbon steel products
text: The Commission has in previous decisions considered the market for the supply of hot-rolled flat carbon steel products in the EEA to constitute a relevant product market. In Arcelor/Mittal, the Commission defined the relevant product market as the market for hot-rolled flat carbon steel products, comprising hot-rolled wide strip, quarto plate and hot-rolled narrow strip. The Commission distinguished hot-rolled flat carbon steel products from other steel products on the basis of their specific production processes and end uses. Furthermore, the Commission considered that from the demand-side perspective, there is a limited substitutability between hot-rolled flat carbon steel products and other steel products (such as long products or cold-rolled flat steel products) due to the specific technical properties required by customers. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact product market definition can be left open, since the Proposed Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market, regardless of whether the relevant product market includes hot-rolled flat carbon steel products or a broader category of steel products.

topic: Market for the supply of hot-rolled wide strip
text: The Commission has previously considered that the market for hot-rolled wide strip could constitute a separate product market. Hot-rolled wide strip is a flat product with a width of 600mm or more, which is rolled at high temperatures. It serves as an input for a large number of applications in various sectors, such as tubes, construction, automotive, shipbuilding, energy and pressure vessels. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact product market definition can be left open, since the Proposed Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market, regardless of whether the relevant product market includes hot-rolled wide strip or a broader category of hot-rolled flat carbon steel products.

topic: Market for the supply of quarto plate
text: The Commission has previously considered that the market for quarto plate could constitute a separate product market. Quarto plate is a flat product with a thickness of 3mm or more, which is rolled individually on a reversing mill. It is mainly used in sectors with high requirements in terms of steel quality, such as shipbuilding, the manufacturing of large pipes, the construction industry or for offshore applications. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact product market definition can be left open, since the Proposed Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market, regardless of whether the relevant product market includes quarto plate or a broader category of hot-rolled flat carbon steel products.

The Commission has previously considered that the market for hot-rolled narrow strip could constitute a separate product market. Hot-rolled narrow strip is a flat product with a width of less than 600mm, which is rolled at high temperatures. It serves as an input for a large number of applications in various sectors, such as tubes, construction, automotive and appliances. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact product market definition can be left open, since the Proposed Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market, regardless of whether the relevant product market includes hot-rolled narrow strip or a broader category of hot-rolled flat carbon steel products.

topic: Supply of cold-rolled flat carbon steel products
text: The Commission has in previous decisions considered the market for the supply of cold-rolled flat carbon steel products in the EEA to constitute a relevant product market. Cold-rolled flat carbon steel products are produced from hot-rolled flat carbon steel products through a cold-rolling process and are used for higher quality surface requirements and/or lower thickness requirements than hot-rolled flat carbon steel products can offer. The Commission has distinguished cold-rolled flat carbon steel products from other steel products on the basis of their specific production processes and end uses. Furthermore, the Commission considered that from the demand-side perspective, there is a limited substitutability between cold-rolled flat carbon steel products and other steel products (such as long products or hot-rolled flat steel products) due to the specific technical properties required by customers. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact product market definition can be left open, since the Proposed Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market, regardless of whether the relevant product market includes cold-rolled flat carbon steel products or a broader category of steel products.

topic: Supply of metallic coated flat carbon steel products
text: The Commission has in previous decisions considered the market for the supply of metallic coated flat carbon steel products in the EEA to constitute a relevant product market. Metallic coated flat carbon steel products are produced from hot-rolled or cold-rolled flat carbon steel products through a metallic coating process (such as galvanising, electrolytic coating, aluminising or other metallic coating). These products are used in applications where resistance against corrosion is required. The Commission has distinguished metallic coated flat carbon steel products from other steel products on the basis of their specific production processes and end uses. Furthermore, the Commission considered that from the demand-side perspective, there is a limited substitutability between metallic coated flat carbon steel products and other steel products (such as long products or uncoated flat steel products) due to the specific technical properties required by customers. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact product market definition can be left open, since the Proposed Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market, regardless of whether the relevant product market includes metallic coated flat carbon steel products or a broader category of steel products.

topic: Supply of organic coated flat carbon steel products
text: The Commission has in previous decisions considered the market for the supply of organic coated flat carbon steel products in the EEA to constitute a relevant product market. Organic coated flat carbon steel products are produced from hot-rolled, cold-rolled or metallic coated flat carbon steel products through an organic coating process (such as painting, film coating or other organic coating). These products are used in a wide variety of applications, such as construction, appliances or automotive. The Commission has distinguished organic coated flat carbon steel products from other steel products on the basis of their specific production processes and end uses. Furthermore, the Commission considered that from the demand-side perspective, there is a limited substitutability between organic coated flat carbon steel products and other steel products (such as long products or uncoated flat steel products) due to the specific technical properties required by customers. For the purpose of the present decision, the exact product market definition can be left open, since the Proposed Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market, regardless of whether the relevant product market includes organic coated flat carbon steel products or a broader category of steel products.

The Commission considers that it is not necessary to define the precise product or geographic markets in this case given that, even assuming that the narrowest possible market definition is adopted, the conduct in question does not, in any event, appear capable of restricting competition to an appreciable extent within the meaning of Article 101 TFEU.

topic: Product Market Definition for Subaru Motor Vehicles
text: As regards the product market, Carpenter considers that the relevant product market is the market for the distribution and servicing of Subaru motor vehicles.

topic: Geographic Market Definition in the Czech Republic
text: As regards the geographic market, Carpenter considers that the relevant geographic market is at least national in scope, given the different conditions of competition prevailing in the Czech Republic.

La Commission est parvenue à la conclusion qu'i l est peu probable que l es faits mentionnés par Interactive Lab au soutien des allégations soulevées dans sa plainte soient avérés. En effet, ces allégations, qui se recoupent en grande partie, sont fondées sur l'hypothèse selon laquelle le mécanisme de sélection des publicités AdWords affichées sur la page de résultats de recherche générale de Google serait différent de celui publiquement décrit par Google. Au lieu de classer les publicités candidates dans l'ordre du produit de l'enchère proposée par l'annonceur et du taux de clic préd it ("pCTR") sur l'annonce candidate, puis d'afficher les premières annonces dans l'ordre de ce classement, Google procéderait en réalité à une rotation ("dispatching d'audience") des annonceurs afin d'exposer périodiquement les publicités de chacun sans rapport avec leur enchère ou la qualité réelle de leur annonce. Google parviendrait à ce résultat en manipulant le score de qualité des publicités candidates, le score de qualité étant l'élément de base du calcul du pCTR.

topic: Sales of spark plugs to car manufacturers
text: In this case the relevant value of sales is the sales of spark plugs supplied to car manufacturers with production facilities in the EEA (as set out in Section 4).

In the Union, braking systems are produced notably in Germany, France, United Kingdom, Poland and the Czech Republic. The customers concerned are large car producing multi -nationals which are present across the whole of the EEA.

In via preliminare, la Commissione osserva che per accertare l'esistenza di una violation delle norme del diritto della concorrenza dell’Unione è necessario definire i mercati rilevanti nei quali si ritiene che tali pratiche abbiano avuto luogo. Nel caso di specie, per procedere alla definizione dei mercati rilevanti la Commissione dovrebbe adottare misure istruttorie e inviare richieste di informazioni. Ciò risulta tanto più necessario in quanto Lei non ha fornito, nelle Sue osservazioni, elementi a sostegno di quella che secondo Lei potrebbe essere la definizione dei mercati rilevanti nel caso di specie.

The Commission’s investigation concerns baseband chipsets that comply with 3G (UMTS) and 4G (LTE) standards and are used to deliver cellular mobile connectivity in smartphones and tablets (‘baseband chipsets’).

topic: Organisation and commercial exploitation of international speed skating events
text: This market encompasses the organisation and commercial exploitation of international speed skating events (i.e. events in speed skating, figure skating and synchronised skating) worldwide. These events generate revenues from media rights, sponsorship, ticketing and merchandising.

topic: Provision of speed skating services to athletes
text: This market encompasses the provision of speed skating services to athletes (i.e. speed skaters, figure skaters and synchronised skaters) worldwide. These services include inter alia the provision of opportunities to participate in speed skating events, the provision of training and coaching, and the provision of medical and other support services.

topic: Provision of services of officials at speed skating events
text: This market encompasses the provision of services of officials at speed skating events (i.e. judges, referees, timekeepers, etc.) worldwide.

topic: Geographic market for the organisation and commercial exploitation of international speed skating events, for the provision of speed skating services to athletes, and for the provision of services of officials at speed skating events
text: The Commission considers that the relevant geographic market for the organisation and commercial exploitation of international speed skating events, for the provision of speed skating services to athletes, and for the provision of services of officials at speed skating events is likely to be worldwide, as the ISU is the sole organisation governing these activities at a global level.

topic: Payments made via mobile wallets in physical stores on smart mobile devices running on iOS and iPadOS
text: With regard to (i) above, the Commission will investigate in particular whether payments made via mobile wallets in physical stores using smart mobile devices running on iOS and iPadOS form a separate market to (a) payments made via mobile wallets in physical stores using smart mobile devices running on other operating systems (such as Android); and (b) payments made via other means (such as cash, credit cards, or other forms of payment) in physical stores.

topic: Payments made via mobile wallets online on smart mobile devices running on iOS and iPadOS
text: With regard to (ii) above, the Commission will investigate in particular whether payments made via mobile wallets online using smart mobile devices running on iOS and iPadOS form a separate market to payments made via other means online.

topic: Provision of mobile wallets on smart mobile devices running on iOS and iPadOS
text: Finally, with regard to (iii) above, the Commission will investigate whether the provision of mobile wallets on smart mobile devices running on iOS and iPadOS forms a separate market to the provision of mobile wallets on smart mobile devices running on other operating systems (such as Android).

The Parties submit that the relevant product market is that of axles (including complete axle assemblies) for commercial vehicles (trucks and buses). They further submit that axles for trucks and buses do not constitute a separate market from axles for trailers. They consider that the demand-side substitutability between axles for trucks and buses and axles for trailers is high because the same OEMs purchase both types of axles for manufacturing trucks/buses and trailers and could easily switch their demand between suppliers of the different types of axles. On the supply side, the Parties submit that most axle manufacturers produce both types of axles and can easily switch production between them. The Commission’s previous case practice supports the view that axles for trucks and buses may constitute a relevant product market. However, it has not previously considered the scope of the product market with respect to the inclusion of axles for trailers. For the purpose of this decision, the exact product market definition can be left open since the Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market under any alternative product market definition considered.

The Parties submit that the relevant product market is that of hydraulic braking systems and components for commercial vehicles (trucks and buses), including both new and aftermarket products. They submit that hydraulic braking systems and components for commercial vehicles do not constitute a separate market from hydraulic braking systems and components for trailers. They consider that the demand-side substitutability between hydraulic braking systems and components for trucks and buses and hydraulic braking systems and components for trailers is high because the same OEMs purchase both types of hydraulic braking systems and components for manufacturing trucks/buses and trailers and could easily switch their demand between suppliers of the different types of hydraulic braking systems and components. On the supply side, the Parties submit that most hydraulic braking systems and component manufacturers produce both types of hydraulic braking systems and components and can easily switch production between them. The Commission has not previously considered the scope of the product market with respect to the inclusion of hydraulic braking systems and components for trailers. For the purpose of this decision, the exact product market definition can be left open since the Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market under any alternative product market definition considered.

The Parties submit that the relevant product market is that of air disc brakes (‘ADB’) for commercial vehicles (trucks and buses), including both new and aftermarket products. They submit that ADBs for trucks and buses do not constitute a separate market from ADBs for trailers. They consider that the demand-side substitutability between ADBs for trucks and buses and ADBs for trailers is high because the same OEMs purchase both types of ADBs for manufacturing trucks/buses and trailers and could easily switch their demand between suppliers of the different types of ADBs. On the supply side, the Parties submit that most ADB manufacturers produce both types of ADBs and can easily switch production between them. The Commission has not previously considered the scope of the product market with respect to the inclusion of ADBs for trailers. For the purpose of this decision, the exact product market definition can be left open since the Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market under any alternative product market definition considered.

The Parties submit that the relevant product market is that of automatic slack adjusters (‘ASA’) for commercial vehicles (trucks and buses), including both new and aftermarket products. They submit that ASAs for trucks and buses do not constitute a separate market from ASAs for trailers. They consider that the demand-side substitutability between ASAs for trucks and buses and ASAs for trailers is high because the same OEMs purchase both types of ASAs for manufacturing trucks/buses and trailers and could easily switch their demand between suppliers of the different types of ASAs. On the supply side, the Parties submit that most ASA manufacturers produce both types of ASAs and can easily switch production between them. The Commission has not previously considered the scope of the product market with respect to the inclusion of ASAs for trailers. For the purpose of this decision, the exact product market definition can be left open since the Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market under any alternative product market definition considered.

The Parties submit that the relevant product market is that of actuators for commercial vehicles, including both new and aftermarket products. Actuators are components used in braking systems. The Parties submit that actuators for trucks and buses do not constitute a separate market from actuators for trailers. They consider that the demand-side substitutability between actuators for trucks and buses and actuators for trailers is high because the same OEMs purchase both types of actuators for manufacturing trucks/buses and trailers and could easily switch their demand between suppliers of the different types of actuators. On the supply side, the Parties submit that most actuator manufacturers produce both types of actuators and can easily switch production between them. The Commission has not previously considered the scope of the product market with respect to the inclusion of actuators for trailers. For the purpose of this decision, the exact product market definition can be left open since the Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market under any alternative product market definition considered.

The Parties submit that the relevant product market is that of corner modules for commercial vehicles, including both new and aftermarket products. Corner modules are integrated systems incorporating, inter alia, wheel hubs, brakes (including actuators) and wheel-end bearings. The Parties submit that corner modules for trucks and buses do not constitute a separate market from corner modules for trailers. They consider that the demand-side substitutability between corner modules for trucks and buses and corner modules for trailers is high because the same OEMs purchase both types of corner modules for manufacturing trucks/buses and trailers and could easily switch their demand between suppliers of the different types of corner modules. On the supply side, the Parties submit that most corner module manufacturers produce both types of corner modules and can easily switch production between them. The Commission has not previously considered the scope of the product market with respect to the inclusion of corner modules for trailers. For the purpose of this decision, the exact product market definition can be left open since the Transaction does not raise serious doubts as to its compatibility with the internal market under any alternative product market definition considered.

topic: OES Lighting Systems sales after the end of series production in the EEA
text: The basic amount of the fine to be imposed on the undertakings concerned is to be set by reference to the value of their sales, that is to say the value of the undertakings' sales of goods or services to which the infringement directly or indirectly relates in the relevant geographic area in the EEA. In this case the relevant value of sales is OES Lighting Systems sales after the end of series production in the EEA.

topic: Adjusted and adapted basic amounts for undertakings
text:
The explanations in recitals (10) to (22) of this Decision show that the same underlying methodology was applied to all addressees of the 2014 Decision in order to adjust their respective basic amounts according to their particular situation. The explanations also show why the Commission decided to apply different individual reductions and the elements that were taken into account when setting those reductions. In its reply to the letter of 29 March 2017, Printeos also claimed that the adjusted basic amounts showed a clear discrepancy as regards the 10% legal maximum. However, contrary to what Printeos seems to suggest, the reductions were not set at a level that would ensure that the relationship between the adjusted basic amounts and the overall turnover would be the same for all parties. It also must be borne in mind, that according to settled case-law it is not contrary to the principles of proportionality and equal treatment that, through the application of the method of calculation of the basic amount of fines, an undertaking may receive a fine which represents a proportion of its overall turnover that is greater than that represented by the fines imposed respectively on each of the other undertakings. The Commission considers that the methodology used takes into account the parties’ positions in a non-discriminatory manner and results in fair, proportionate and sufficiently deterrent fines for all addressees of the 2014 Decision. The Commission does therefore not see the need to grant a higher reduction to Printeos.

The products concerned by the infringement are defined as stock/catalogue envelopes and special printed (transactional and/or bespoke) envelopes of all shapes, colours and sizes.

In the past, the Commission has considered the markets for methanol and carbon monoxide in the context of the chemicals sector. It has previously investigated a number of Cases where methanol and carbon monoxide were used as raw materials in the production of other chemical products. In those cases, the Commission left the precise product market definition open, as the investigations did not give rise to concerns, irrespective of the product market definition adopted. For the purposes of this Decision, the precise product market definition with regard to methanol and carbon monoxide can be left open, as the Transaction does not give rise to any competition concerns under any plausible market definition.

topic: Downstream markets for products using Chloromethanes
text: The Parties submit that the relevant product markets in the downstream markets for products using chloromethanes are at least as wide as the product markets for the respective downstream products themselves. The Commission has previously considered the product markets for downstream products using chloromethanes, such as, inter alia, fluoropolymers, silicones, pharmaceutical products, agrochemical products, methyl cellulose and quaternary ammonium compounds. In a previous decision, the Commission found that the relevant product markets in the downstream markets for products using chloromethanes could be defined narrowly as the markets for the individual end uses of chloromethanes. However, the Commission left the precise scope of the relevant product markets open. For the purposes of this Decision, the precise scope of the relevant product markets in the downstream markets for products using chloromethanes can be left open, since the Transaction does not give rise to any competition concerns under any plausible market definition.

The Parties submit that silanes can be grouped according to the number of functional groups attached to the silicon atom as “mono-”, “di-”, “tri-” and “tetra-functional silanes”. Furthermore, silanes may be grouped into organo-functional silanes (possessing at least one organic group) and non-organo-functional silanes (in which all functional groups are inorganic). The Parties submit that, based on their different chemical properties, different groups of silanes cannot be considered as substitutable on either the supply or demand side. In a previous decision, the Commission considered that, based on their different chemical properties, different silanes may not be substitutable on either the supply or demand side and that the relevant product markets may be as narrow as each individual silane product. However, the Commission left the precise scope of the relevant product markets open. For the purposes of this Decision, the precise scope of the relevant product markets for silanes can be left open, since the Transaction does not give rise to any competition concerns under any plausible market definition.

The Parties submit that ethyleneamines can be grouped into EDA, DETA, TETA, TEPA, E100 and HEA. According to the Parties, EDA and DETA are the most important ethyleneamines in terms of sales value. The Parties submit that, based on their different chemical properties, different groups of ethyleneamines cannot be considered as substitutable on either the supply or demand side. In a previous decision, the Commission considered that, based on their different chemical properties, different ethyleneamines may not be substitutable on either the supply or demand side and that the relevant product markets may be as narrow as each individual ethyleneamine product. However, the Commission left the precise scope of the relevant product markets open. For the purposes of this Decision, the precise scope of the relevant product markets for ethyleneamines can be left open, since the Transaction does not give rise to any competition concerns under any plausible market definition.

The Parties submit that specialty amines can be grouped into alkylamines (such as, for example, n-propylamine, isopropylamine, n-butylamine, isobutylamine, di-n-butylamine and tertiary butylamine), morpholine, DMAPA and polyetheramines. The Parties submit that, based on their different chemical properties, different groups of specialty amines cannot be considered as substitutable on either the supply or demand side. In a previous decision, the Commission considered that, based on their different chemical properties, different specialty amines may not be substitutable on either the supply or demand side and that the relevant product markets may be as narrow as each individual specialty amine product. However, the Commission left the precise scope of the relevant product markets open. For the purposes of this Decision, the precise scope of the relevant product markets for specialty amines can be left open, since the Transaction does not give rise to any competition concerns under any plausible market definition.

topic: Banking services to MSBs (Money Service Businesses)
text: The Commission concludes that there is a limited likelihood of establishing an infringement of Article 102 TFEU. This is because even if the market were to be defined in the narrowest possible way, that is, the provision of banking services to MSBs (or even money remitters), it is unlikely that Clearing Bank 1 would be in a dominant position in the UK.

topic: Definition of relevant product markets related to the supply of electricity
text: The Parties submit that the relevant product markets encompass the supply of electricity. The Commission’s case practice confirms that electricity constitutes a distinct product market, because it is technically and economically distinct from other energy sources. Electricity cannot be stored easily and must be produced at the time of consumption. The Commission’s case practice distinguishes between: (i) wholesale supply of electricity, and (ii) retail supply of electricity. The Commission’s case practice has further distinguished between base load and peak load electricity, with base load electricity generally being generated by nuclear or lignite plants and peak load electricity generally being generated by gas turbines or pumped storage plants. In any event, it is not necessary to conclude on the precise product market definition, since no competition concerns would arise under any alternative market definition.

topic: Definition of the relevant geographic markets related to the supply of electricity
text: The Parties submit that, according to the Commission's established case practice, the geographic market for wholesale supply of electricity can be defined as national. The Commission’s case practice has found that wholesale electricity markets are still national in scope, mainly due to insufficient interconnector capacity, national regulation, grid management and dispatch responsibilities. However, the Commission’s case practice has also acknowledged that the geographic market definition may be wider than national where there is sufficient interconnection capacity between two countries. It is not necessary to conclude on the precise geographic market definition, since no competition concerns would arise under any alternative market definition.

topic: Definition of the relevant product markets related to balancing services
text: The Parties submit that the relevant product market encompasses balancing services, which are ancillary services that Transmission System Operators (“TSOs”) purchase to ensure continuous matching of electricity supply and demand in real time and to maintain the stability of the grid. The Commission’s case practice confirms that balancing services constitute a distinct product market, because they are technically and economically distinct from other services. Balancing services can be divided into different categories depending on the time frame in which they are provided (frequency containment reserve (“FCR”), frequency restoration reserve with manual activation (“FRR manual”), frequency restoration reserve with automatic activation (“FRR automatic”) and replacement reserve (“RR”)). It is not necessary to conclude on the precise product market definition, since no competition concerns would arise under any alternative market definition.

topic: Definition of the relevant geographic markets related to balancing services
text: The Parties submit that, according to the Commission's established case practice, the geographic market for balancing services can be defined as national. The Commission’s case practice has found that balancing services markets are still national in scope, mainly due to national regulation and the fact that TSOs are responsible for ensuring the stability of the grid in their respective geographic area. It is not necessary to conclude on the precise geographic market definition, since no competition concerns would arise under any alternative market definition.
The Commission’s investigation concerns agreements for the supply of e-books. Therefore, the relevant product market comprises the sale of e-books.

As regards the geographic scope of the relevant market, the Commission considers that this should be assessed nationally, as also found in the framework of previous investigations in the e-books sector. In particular, language specific e-books are only substitutable to a limited extent. Moreover, agreements with publishers are often concluded on a country-by-country basis.

The Complain t concerns a single city airport. While Bromma Stockholm Airport seems to be the fifth largest Swedish airport in terms of passenger numbers (in 2014, it served 2.4 million passengers), its operations tend to be mainly regional in scope. It has limited international links, serving just four scheduled international destinations as opposed to 13 domestic ones. Its top three destinations are all located in Sweden: Malmö, Gothenburg and Umeå. It has one runway of 1,600 m, three shops and two restaurants.

In the framework of the Amazon case, the Commission defined the product market as electronic books (‘e-books’). E-books are digital books read on a computer, dedicated e-reader or other electronic device. The Commission considered that e-books do not belong to the same product market as printed books. The Commission also considered that a further segmentation of the e-book market could be envisaged along language lines. However, in the Amazon case, the Commission left the precise product market definition open, since no competition concerns arose under any alternative market definition considered.

The Concession relates to the horse race betting market. The Complaint alleges that Intralot has been foreclosed from that market in breach of Article 102 TFEU. Therefore, the Commission first analyses whether the size of the horse race betting market is sufficient to have an impact on the functioning of the internal market.

Whereas the Concession relates to horse race betting only, the Complaint alleges that the granting of the Concession will have an impact on competitors' ability to compete on the broader market for online sports betting if this market is liberalised in 2020. The Complainant argues that the Concession is one of the very few realistic means of accessing land-based points of sale and establishing a brand presence in order to compete on the online sports betting market in Greece as from 2020. Therefore, the Commission also analysed whether the award of the Concession – and consequently the alleged anti-competitive conduct – could have and impact on the online sports betting market.

Your Reply alleges that the Commission has taken an overly narrow approach by not assessing the potential impact of OPAP's alleged conduct on the broader online gambling market in Greece.
Based on the information provided by the Complaint and further submissions (see recital (13)), the online gambling market, which entails the online sports betting market but also other forms of online gaming, amounts to 3.5-4.5% of the entire Greek gambling market.
The Commission will also continue monitoring the practices of investment banks in financial markets, including in the credit default swaps sector.

The Commission’s investigation concerns the market for CDS information. CDS information includes CDS transaction data (actual CDS trades with all the trade parameters), CDS valuation data (pricing information for CDS contracts, in particular end-of-day consensus mid quotes) and CDS index composition data (information on which entities are included in a given CDS index).

The relevant services are deep-sea container liner shipping services. They involve the provision of regular, scheduled services for the carriage of containerised cargo by sea. They can be distinguished from non-liner shipping (tramp, specialized transport) because of the regularity and the frequency of the service. Furthermore, they can be distinguished from non-containerized transport such as bulk vessel.

topic: Transport of refrigerated goods in containers
text: A possible narrower service market may be that for the transport of refrigerated goods in containers, which could be limited to reefer containers only. However, since the vast majority of the price increase announcements of the Parties were made for containers of all kinds, there is no need, for the purposes of this Decision, to distinguish between potential submarkets according to the type of containers.
